<<<api>>>: Iterator.next
<<<code>>>:

You can use a map to group the numbers by their respective groups. Here's an example code snippet:
```java
Map<String, List<Integer>> groupNumbers = new HashMap<>();

for (DataSnapshot dataSnapshot1 : dataSnapshot.getChildren()) {
    String group = dataSnapshot1.getKey();
    List<Integer> numbers = groupNumbers.get(group);
    if (numbers == null) {
        numbers = new ArrayList<>();
        groupNumbers.put(group, numbers);
    }
    numbers.add(dataSnapshot1.getChildren().iterator().next().getKey());
}
```
This code will group the numbers by their respective groups (A, B, and C) and store them in the `groupNumbers` map. The `getChildren()` method is called on each `DataSnapshot` object to get the child nodes, and the key of each child node is added to the respective group list. If a group does not exist, a new list is created and added to the map.

Once you have the grouped numbers, you can access them using the `groupNumbers` map like this:
```java
for (Map.Entry<String, List<Integer>> entry : groupNumbers.entrySet()) {
    String group = entry.getKey();
    List<Integer> numbers = entry.getValue();
    // Do something with the numbers in the group
}
```
This code will iterate over all the entries in the `groupNumbers` map and print the group name and the list of numbers in each group. You can replace the `// Do something with the numbers in the group` comment with your own code to process the numbers in each group.
